guides.title: Email Copy Standards
guides.content:
# Email Copy Standards

This guide covers everything you need to write high-converting cold emails that land in the inbox and get responses.

---

## Subject Line Rules

### Length
- **Optimal:** 30-50 characters (4-7 words)
- **Mobile cutoff:** 35-40 characters
- **Never exceed:** 60 characters

### Personalization Requirements
- Always include `{{firstName}}` OR `{{companyName}}`
- Personalized subject lines get 26% higher open rates
- Example: `{{firstName}}, quick question about {{companyName}}`

### Power Words That Work
- Quick, Question, Idea, Noticed, Thought
- Exclusive, Limited, Personalized
- Growth, Scale, Revenue, Results

### Spam Triggers to AVOID
❌ FREE, GUARANTEED, ACT NOW, LIMITED TIME
❌ All caps anything
❌ Excessive punctuation (!!!, ???)
❌ Dollar signs or percentages ($$$, 100%)
❌ "Click here", "Buy now", "Order today"

---

## Body Structure

### The 3-Part Framework

**1. Hook (1-2 sentences)**
- Reference something specific about them
- Show you did research
- Create curiosity

**2. Value Proposition (2-3 sentences)**
- What you do + who you help
- Specific result or outcome
- Social proof if possible

**3. CTA (1 sentence)**
- One clear ask
- Low commitment
- Easy to respond to

### Example Structure
```
Hey {{firstName}},

[HOOK] Saw {{companyName}} just expanded into [market] — congrats!

[VALUE] We help [similar companies] book 15-20 qualified demos/month 
through targeted outbound. Recently did this for [client name].

[CTA] Worth a quick chat to see if we could help {{companyName}}?

{{senderName}}
```

---

## Personalization Requirements

### Required Merge Fields
- `{{firstName}}` — Recipient's first name
- `{{companyName}}` — Their company
- `{{senderName}}` — Your strategist's name
- `{{senderCompany}}` — Client's company name

### Recommended Merge Fields
- `{{title}}` — Their job title
- `{{industry}}` — Their industry
- `{{companySize}}` — Employee count tier
- `{{location}}` — City or region

### Custom Personalization
- Add 1 unique line per prospect when possible
- Reference: recent news, LinkedIn post, company milestone
- This single line can 2-3x reply rates

---

## Spintax Usage Guidelines

### What Is Spintax?
Spintax creates variations to avoid spam filters detecting identical emails.

### Syntax
`{Option 1|Option 2|Option 3}`

### Where to Use
✅ Greetings: `{Hey|Hi|Hello}`
✅ Transitions: `{I noticed|I saw|I came across}`
✅ CTAs: `{Worth a chat?|Open to connecting?|Interested in learning more?}`
✅ Sign-offs: `{Best|Cheers|Thanks}`

### Where NOT to Use
❌ Company names
❌ Specific claims or numbers
❌ Core value proposition
❌ Personalization fields

### Best Practices
- Use 3-5 spintax variations per email
- Keep variations natural and equivalent
- Test all variations read well

---

## Tone and Voice

### The Target Tone
- **Conversational** — Like you're emailing a colleague
- **Confident** — You know what you're talking about
- **Helpful** — Focused on their benefit
- **Concise** — Respect their time

### Do's
✅ Write at an 8th-grade reading level
✅ Use "you" more than "I" or "we"
✅ Short sentences (under 20 words)
✅ One idea per paragraph
✅ Sound human, not robotic

### Don'ts
❌ Formal corporate speak
❌ Jargon or buzzwords
❌ Desperate or needy tone
❌ Arrogant or pushy
❌ Generic templates that sound mass-sent

---

## What NOT to Do

### Spam Words to Avoid
| Category | Words to Avoid |
|----------|----------------|
| Urgency | Act now, Limited time, Don't miss, Hurry |
| Money | Free, Cheap, Discount, $$, Save big |
| Promises | Guaranteed, No risk, 100%, Promise |
| Pressure | You must, Required, Mandatory |
| Hype | Amazing, Incredible, Revolutionary |

### Pushy Language Examples
❌ "I know you're busy, but..."
❌ "Just following up for the 5th time..."
❌ "I haven't heard back from you..."
❌ "Did you get my last email?"
❌ "I really think you should..."

### Formatting Mistakes
❌ Multiple CTAs (pick ONE)
❌ Walls of text (break it up)
❌ Too many links (max 1-2)
❌ Images in cold emails (triggers spam)
❌ HTML formatting (plain text performs better)
❌ Long signatures with logos

### Length Mistakes
❌ Over 150 words (aim for 75-120)
❌ More than 5 sentences in body
❌ Paragraphs over 2 sentences

---

## Quick Checklist Before Sending

- [ ] Subject line under 50 characters?
- [ ] Includes personalization?
- [ ] Under 150 words?
- [ ] Single, clear CTA?
- [ ] No spam trigger words?
- [ ] Reads naturally out loud?
- [ ] Would YOU reply to this email?

guides.title: Subject Line Best Practices
guides.content:
# Subject Line Best Practices

Your subject line determines whether your email gets opened. 47% of recipients open emails based on subject line alone. This guide will help you write subject lines that get clicks.

---

## Optimal Length

### The Sweet Spot: 30-50 Characters

| Length | Open Rate Impact | Mobile Display |
|--------|-----------------|----------------|
| Under 30 chars | Good | Full display |
| 30-50 chars | **Best** | Full display |
| 50-60 chars | Declining | Partial cutoff |
| Over 60 chars | Poor | Heavy cutoff |

### Word Count Target
- **Ideal:** 4-7 words
- **Maximum:** 9 words
- **Minimum:** 3 words

### Why Length Matters
- 55% of emails opened on mobile
- iPhone shows ~35-38 characters
- Android shows ~33-43 characters
- Front-load the important words

---

## Personalization Patterns

### High-Performing Patterns

**Pattern 1: Name + Topic**
```
{{firstName}}, quick question
{{firstName}}, idea for {{companyName}}
```

**Pattern 2: Company Focus**
```
{{companyName}}'s outbound strategy
Thoughts on {{companyName}}'s growth
```

**Pattern 3: Mutual Connection**
```
{{mutualConnection}} suggested I reach out
Following up from {{eventName}}
```

**Pattern 4: Research-Based**
```
Re: your {{recentPost}} post
Loved your take on {{topic}}
```

### Personalization Impact
- First name: +26% open rate
- Company name: +22% open rate
- Both combined: +35% open rate

---

## Power Words That Work

### Curiosity Triggers
- Question
- Idea
- Thought
- Quick
- Noticed

### Value Signals
- Strategy
- Growth
- Results
- Opportunity
- Insights

### Exclusivity
- Personalized
- Specifically
- For [Company]
- Your team

### Soft Urgency (Use Sparingly)
- This week
- Before [Date]
- Q1 planning

### Example Subject Lines Using Power Words
✅ `Quick question about {{companyName}}'s pipeline`
✅ `Noticed something about your outbound`
✅ `Growth idea for {{firstName}}`
✅ `Thought on {{companyName}}'s Q1 strategy`

---

## Words to Avoid

### Spam Filter Triggers
❌ FREE, GUARANTEED, ACT NOW
❌ LIMITED TIME OFFER
❌ YOU WON, WINNER, SELECTED
❌ URGENT, IMPORTANT
❌ $$, %, OFF

### Overused & Ignored
❌ "Touching base"
❌ "Following up"
❌ "Checking in"
❌ "Hope you're well"
❌ "Quick sync"

### Trust Killers
❌ "RE:" when it's not a reply
❌ "FWD:" fake forwards
❌ "URGENT" when it's not
❌ Clickbait that doesn't deliver

### Formatting Mistakes
❌ ALL CAPS (looks like spam)
❌ Excessive punctuation!!!
❌ [Brackets] or {Braces}
❌ Emojis (test carefully, usually hurt B2B)
❌ Numbers at the start

---

## A/B Testing Tips

### What to Test

1. **Personalization placement**
   - A: `{{firstName}}, quick question`
   - B: `Quick question, {{firstName}}`

2. **Specificity level**
   - A: `Question about your outbound`
   - B: `Question about {{companyName}}'s outbound`

3. **Tone**
   - A: `Idea for {{companyName}}` (direct)
   - B: `Thought you might find this useful` (soft)

4. **Length**
   - A: `{{firstName}} - growth idea` (short)
   - B: `{{firstName}}, thought on scaling {{companyName}}'s pipeline` (longer)

### Testing Best Practices
- Test ONE variable at a time
- Minimum 100 sends per variant
- Run for at least 48 hours
- Statistical significance > gut feeling
- Document what works for each ICP

### How to Measure
- **Open rate** is primary metric
- **Reply rate** is secondary (some subject lines get opens but not replies)
- Track by industry, title, company size

---

## Examples: Good vs Bad

### ✅ Good Subject Lines

| Subject Line | Why It Works |
|-------------|-------------|
| `{{firstName}}, quick question` | Short, personal, curiosity |
| `Idea for {{companyName}}'s outbound` | Specific, value-focused |
| `Noticed {{companyName}} is hiring SDRs` | Research-based, relevant |
| `Thoughts on your LinkedIn post` | Shows genuine interest |
| `Question about scaling {{companyName}}` | Implies value, specific |
| `{{firstName}} ↔ {{senderName}} intro` | Mutual, peer-level |

### ❌ Bad Subject Lines

| Subject Line | Why It Fails |
|-------------|-------------|
| `URGENT: Don't miss this opportunity!!!` | Spam triggers, pushy |
| `Following up` | Vague, overused |
| `Our incredible service will transform your business` | Hype, too long, no personalization |
| `RE: Our conversation` | Fake reply, trust killer |
| `Free consultation available now` | Spam words |
| `Hi` | Too short, no value |

---

## Subject Line Templates by Scenario

### Initial Outreach
```
{{firstName}}, quick question about {{companyName}}
{{companyName}}'s outbound — idea
Thought on {{companyName}}'s pipeline
Noticed something about {{companyName}}
```

### Follow-ups
```
{{firstName}}?
Re: {{companyName}}'s outbound
One more thought
This might help {{companyName}}
```

### Breakup Emails
```
Should I close your file?
Not a fit?
Last one, {{firstName}}
```

---

## Quick Reference

| Element | Guideline |
|---------|----------|
| Length | 30-50 characters |
| Words | 4-7 words |
| Personalization | Always include |
| Caps | Sentence case only |
| Punctuation | Minimal, no !!! |
| Emojis | Avoid for B2B |
| Testing | One variable at a time |

guides.title: Follow-up Sequence Guidelines
guides.content:
# Follow-up Sequence Guidelines

80% of sales require 5+ follow-ups, but 44% of reps give up after one. This guide ensures your sequences are persistent without being annoying.

---

## Timing Between Emails

### Recommended Sequence Timing

| Email | Days After Previous | Purpose |
|-------|--------------------|---------|
| Email 1 | Day 0 | Initial outreach |
| Email 2 | Day 2-3 | First follow-up |
| Email 3 | Day 5-7 | Value add |
| Email 4 | Day 10-14 | Different angle |
| Email 5 | Day 21-28 | Breakup email |

### Why 2-3 Days Works
- Enough time to read and respond
- Short enough to stay relevant
- Creates gentle urgency
- Accounts for busy schedules

### Timing Adjustments
- **Executives (C-level):** Add 1-2 days between emails
- **Mid-level:** Standard timing
- **Urgency campaigns:** Can tighten to 1-2 days
- **Long sales cycles:** Extend to 5-7 days between

### Day/Time Best Practices
- **Best days:** Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday
- **Best times:** 8-10 AM or 2-4 PM (recipient's timezone)
- **Avoid:** Monday morning, Friday afternoon, weekends

---

## How Follow-ups Should Reference Previous Emails

### The Right Way

**Soft reference (Preferred):**
```
Hey {{firstName}},

Bumping this up in case it got buried — thought this could 
be relevant for {{companyName}}'s outbound goals.
```

**Thread continuation:**
```
Hey {{firstName}},

Wanted to add one more thought to my previous note...
```

**New value:**
```
{{firstName}},

Since I last reached out, we just helped [Client] achieve 
[result]. Thought this might be relevant for {{companyName}}.
```

### The Wrong Way

❌ "Did you get my last email?"
❌ "I haven't heard back from you..."
❌ "Following up for the 4th time..."
❌ "I know I've emailed a few times, but..."
❌ "Just checking if you saw my message"

### Thread Management
- Follow-ups should be replies to the original thread
- Same subject line (RE: auto-added)
- Keeps context visible
- Improves deliverability (ongoing conversation)

---

## Keeping It Short

### Follow-up Length Guidelines

| Email | Max Words | Max Sentences |
|-------|-----------|---------------|
| Email 1 | 100-125 | 4-5 |
| Email 2 | 50-75 | 2-3 |
| Email 3 | 75-100 | 3-4 |
| Email 4 | 50-75 | 2-3 |
| Email 5 | 50-60 | 2-3 |

### Why Shorter Is Better
- Shows respect for their time
- Easier to read on mobile
- Forces you to be clear
- Higher response rates

### Short Follow-up Templates

**Email 2 (Day 2-3):**
```
{{firstName}} — bumping this up.

Worth a quick chat this week?

{{senderName}}
```

**Email 3 (Day 5-7):**
```
Hey {{firstName}},

Thought this case study might be relevant — [link]. 
Shows how we helped [similar company] with [result].

Interested in seeing if this could work for {{companyName}}?
```

---

## When to Break Up / Give Value

### Adding Value in Sequence

Not every follow-up should ask for a meeting. Mix in value:

**Value Email Options:**
- Share relevant case study
- Send helpful article (not yours)
- Offer free resource or template
- Share industry insight
- Reference their recent company news

### Value Email Template
```
Hey {{firstName}},

Not trying to sell you anything with this one — just came 
across [resource] and thought of {{companyName}}.

[Brief explanation of why it's relevant]

{{senderName}}
```

### The Break-Up Email (Email 5)

The breakup email often gets the highest response rate. Why:
- Creates scarcity
- Removes pressure
- Gives them an easy out (which often prompts action)

**Breakup Email Templates:**

**Template 1 - Permission to close:**
```
{{firstName}},

I haven't heard back, so I'm guessing the timing isn't right.

Should I close out your file, or is there a better time 
to reconnect?

{{senderName}}
```

**Template 2 - Simple:**
```
{{firstName}},

Not a fit? No worries — just let me know and I'll stop 
reaching out.

{{senderName}}
```

**Template 3 - Direct:**
```
Last one, {{firstName}}.

If outbound lead gen isn't a priority for {{companyName}} 
right now, totally understand. Just say the word.

{{senderName}}
```

---

## Final Email Best Practices

### What Makes Breakups Work
- Keep it under 50 words
- No guilt trips
- Give them an easy out
- Ask a yes/no question
- Make it easy to respond

### What NOT to Do in Final Emails
❌ "I've tried reaching you multiple times..."
❌ "I'm confused why you haven't responded"
❌ "This is my last email" (then sending more)
❌ Passive-aggressive tone
❌ Long explanations of why they should respond

### After the Breakup
- Wait 30-60 days before re-engaging
- Re-approach with new angle/trigger event
- Don't reference the old sequence
- Treat it as a fresh start

---

## Complete Sequence Example

### Email 1 (Day 0) — Initial Outreach
```
Subject: {{firstName}}, quick question about {{companyName}}

Hey {{firstName}},

Saw {{companyName}} is scaling the sales team — congrats 
on the growth.

We help B2B SaaS companies book 15-20 qualified demos/month 
through targeted cold email. Just helped [similar company] 
hit that number last quarter.

Worth a quick chat to see if this could work for 
{{companyName}}?

{{senderName}}
```

### Email 2 (Day 3) — Bump
```
{{firstName}} — bumping this up.

Happy to share how we got [result] for [client] if helpful.

{{senderName}}
```

### Email 3 (Day 7) — Value Add
```
Hey {{firstName}},

Thought you might find this useful — here's the exact 
sequence template that's working for our SaaS clients: 
[link to resource]

No strings attached. Let me know if it's helpful.

{{senderName}}
```

### Email 4 (Day 14) — Different Angle
```
{{firstName}},

Curious — is {{companyName}} currently using cold email 
for outbound, or focusing on other channels?

Either way, happy to share what's working in your space.

{{senderName}}
```

### Email 5 (Day 28) — Breakup
```
Last one, {{firstName}}.

If this isn't a priority for {{companyName}} right now, 
just let me know and I'll close out your file.

{{senderName}}
```

---

## Quick Reference

| Principle | Guideline |
|-----------|-----------|
| Timing | 2-3 days between emails |
| Sequence length | 5 emails max |
| Follow-up length | Shorter than previous |
| Value emails | Include 1-2 per sequence |
| Breakup | Always include, keep short |
| After breakup | Wait 30-60 days to re-engage |

guides.title: Lead List Requirements
guides.content:
# Lead List Requirements

Garbage in, garbage out. The quality of your lead list directly determines campaign success. This guide covers everything needed for a clean, high-quality list.

---

## Required Fields

Every lead MUST have these fields:

| Field | Format | Example |
|-------|--------|--------|
| `email` | Valid email address | john@acmecorp.com |
| `first_name` | Proper case | John |
| `last_name` | Proper case | Smith |
| `company` | Full company name | Acme Corporation |
| `title` | Job title | VP of Sales |

### Field Requirements

**Email**
- Must be valid format (x@x.xx)
- Must pass validation (more below)
- No personal emails (gmail, yahoo, etc.) for B2B
- Must be deliverable (verified)

**First Name**
- Proper capitalization (John, not JOHN or john)
- No initials only (J. Smith)
- No nicknames in quotes (John "Johnny")
- No prefixes (Mr., Dr.)

**Last Name**
- Proper capitalization
- No suffixes (Jr., III) unless relevant
- No credentials (MBA, PhD)

**Company**
- Full legal name preferred
- No abbreviations unless well-known (IBM vs. International Business Machines)
- Remove Inc., LLC, Ltd. for cleaner personalization

**Title**
- Actual title, not description
- ✅ "VP of Sales"
- ❌ "Does sales stuff"

---

## Recommended Fields

These fields improve personalization and targeting:

| Field | Format | Purpose |
|-------|--------|--------|
| `industry` | Text | Personalization, segmentation |
| `company_size` | Number or range | ICP matching |
| `linkedin_url` | Full URL | Research, verification |
| `location` | City, State/Country | Timezone, regional targeting |
| `phone` | Formatted number | Multi-channel outreach |
| `website` | Company URL | Research |

### Company Size Tiers
Standardize company size for better segmentation:

| Tier | Employee Count |
|------|---------------|
| SMB | 1-50 |
| Mid-Market | 51-500 |
| Enterprise | 501-5000 |
| Large Enterprise | 5000+ |

---

## Email Validation Rules

### Validation Requirements
All emails must be verified before upload. Use tools like:
- ZeroBounce
- NeverBounce
- Hunter.io
- MillionVerifier

### Acceptable Validation Status
✅ Valid / Deliverable
✅ Accept-all / Catch-all (use cautiously, max 20% of list)

### Reject These
❌ Invalid
❌ Disposable
❌ Spam trap
❌ Unknown (high risk)
❌ Bounce risk > 5%

### Bounce Rate Targets
- **Target:** < 2% bounce rate
- **Acceptable:** < 5% bounce rate
- **Danger zone:** > 5% (pause and clean list)

---

## No Disposable Emails

### What Are Disposable Emails?
Temporary email addresses from services like:
- Mailinator
- Guerrilla Mail
- 10MinuteMail
- Tempmail
- Throwaway domains

### Why They're Dangerous
- Never convert to customers
- Often used by competitors/spam traps
- Waste sending capacity
- Can indicate scraping issues

### Detection
Most email validators flag disposable addresses. Always filter these out.

---

## No Role-Based Emails

### What Are Role-Based Emails?
Generic addresses that go to a group, not an individual:

❌ info@company.com
❌ sales@company.com
❌ support@company.com
❌ admin@company.com
❌ contact@company.com
❌ hello@company.com
❌ team@company.com
❌ careers@company.com
❌ marketing@company.com

### Why They Don't Work
- No personalization possible
- Often routed to spam/ignored
- Lower reply rates
- Can trigger spam filters
- Not decision makers

### Exception
Very small companies (< 5 employees) where founder uses info@ personally. Verify individually.

---

## Deduplication Requirements

### What to Dedupe

**1. Exact email match**
- Remove all duplicate email addresses
- Keep most recent/complete record

**2. Same person, different email**
- john@company.com vs jsmith@company.com
- Use first_name + last_name + company match

**3. Cross-campaign deduplication**
- Check against currently active campaigns
- Check against recent campaigns (last 30-60 days)
- Check against global opt-out list

### Deduplication Process
1. Dedupe within the new list
2. Check against active campaign leads
3. Check against suppression list
4. Check against client exclusion list

### Keeping Records
Maintain a master suppression list:
- All bounced emails
- All unsubscribes
- All "not interested" replies
- All competitor domains

---

## Minimum List Size Recommendations

### By Campaign Type

| Campaign Type | Minimum Leads | Ideal Range |
|--------------|---------------|-------------|
| Test Campaign | 100-200 | 150-300 |
| Standard Campaign | 500-1000 | 1000-3000 |
| Multi-month Campaign | 2000+ | 3000-5000 |
| Enterprise Targeting | 200-500 | 300-500 |

### Why Minimums Matter
- Need statistical significance for testing
- Account for bounces and opt-outs
- Ensure consistent sending volume
- Allow for A/B testing

### Quality vs Quantity
Better to have:
- 500 verified, ICP-matched leads

Than:
- 5000 unverified, loosely-targeted leads

---

## List Hygiene Checklist

### Before Upload
- [ ] All required fields present
- [ ] Emails validated (< 2% estimated bounce)
- [ ] No disposable emails
- [ ] No role-based emails
- [ ] Deduplicated within list
- [ ] Checked against suppression list
- [ ] Checked against active campaigns
- [ ] Titles match ICP decision makers
- [ ] Company size matches ICP
- [ ] Industry verified (if applicable)

### Data Formatting
- [ ] Names properly capitalized
- [ ] No extra whitespace
- [ ] No special characters in names
- [ ] Consistent country/state formatting
- [ ] UTF-8 encoding (no weird characters)
- [ ] CSV or required upload format

---

## Common List Problems

| Problem | Solution |
|---------|----------|
| High bounce rate | Re-verify with different tool, remove catch-alls |
| Low open rates | Check domain reputation, verify list freshness |
| Many "unsubscribes" | List may be too old, or wrong ICP |
| Spam complaints | Stop immediately, review list source |
| Wrong titles | Tighten ICP filters, manual review |
| Too many catch-alls | Mix sources, use intent data |

---

## Data Sources Quality Tier

### Tier 1 - High Quality
- Apollo.io (verified)
- LinkedIn Sales Navigator
- ZoomInfo
- Cognism

### Tier 2 - Good Quality
- Hunter.io
- Lusha
- RocketReach
- Snov.io

### Tier 3 - Use With Caution
- Generic scraping tools
- Purchased lists
- Old databases
- "Unlimited leads" services

Always verify Tier 2-3 sources with email validation before use.

guides.title: ICP Matching Rules
guides.content:
# ICP Matching Rules

ICP (Ideal Customer Profile) matching is the foundation of successful outbound. Wrong ICP = wasted sends, low replies, and frustrated clients. This guide ensures every lead matches the target.

---

## How to Verify Leads Match Client ICP

### The ICP Verification Process

1. **Get written ICP from client** (never assume)
2. **Document specific criteria** (see sections below)
3. **Build filtering rules** in your lead sourcing
4. **Spot-check sample** before full list pull
5. **Review edge cases** with client if unsure

### ICP Documentation Checklist

Before sourcing leads, confirm:
- [ ] Target titles (exact and variations)
- [ ] Company size range (employees and/or revenue)
- [ ] Target industries (and exclusions)
- [ ] Geographic scope
- [ ] Technology/tool requirements (if any)
- [ ] Exclusion list (competitors, existing customers)
- [ ] Any special criteria

---

## Title Matching (Decision Makers)

### Understanding Title Hierarchy

| Level | Examples | Decision Power |
|-------|----------|---------------|
| C-Suite | CEO, CTO, CFO, CMO, CRO | Final decision |
| VP | VP Sales, VP Marketing, VP Ops | Strong influence |
| Director | Director of Sales, Marketing Director | Budget control |
| Manager | Sales Manager, Marketing Manager | Influencer |
| Individual | SDR, AE, Coordinator | Usually not target |

### Title Matching Rules

**Match the buyer, not the user.**

Example: Selling sales automation tool
- ✅ VP of Sales, CRO, Head of Sales (buyers)
- ❌ SDR, AE, Sales Rep (users, not buyers)

**Account for title variations:**
```
Target: VP of Sales

Also include:
- VP, Sales
- Vice President of Sales
- Vice President, Sales
- Sales VP
- Head of Sales
- SVP Sales
- EVP Sales
```

### Title Red Flags

❌ "Intern" or "Assistant" in title
❌ "Coordinator" (usually too junior)
❌ "Consultant" (often not employed there)
❌ "Former" or "Ex-" 
❌ Board member only (not operational)
❌ "Freelance" or "Independent"

### Title Verification
- Cross-reference with LinkedIn
- Check if title makes sense for company size
- Verify they're current (not outdated data)

---

## Company Size Alignment

### Standard Size Brackets

| Segment | Employees | Typical Revenue |
|---------|-----------|----------------|
| Startup | 1-10 | $0-$1M |
| Small | 11-50 | $1M-$10M |
| Mid-Market | 51-200 | $10M-$50M |
| Upper Mid-Market | 201-1000 | $50M-$200M |
| Enterprise | 1001-5000 | $200M-$1B |
| Large Enterprise | 5000+ | $1B+ |

### Why Size Matters

**Too Small:**
- May not have budget
- May not have the problem you solve
- Founder does everything (hard to reach)

**Too Large:**
- Long sales cycles
- Complex procurement
- May already have solution
- May need enterprise sales approach

### Size Verification
- LinkedIn company page
- Company website (about page)
- Apollo, ZoomInfo data
- Recent funding announcements

### Common Mistakes
❌ Using outdated size data (companies grow/shrink)
❌ Confusing subsidiary size with parent company
❌ Including franchise locations as separate companies
❌ Not accounting for recent layoffs/growth

---

## Industry Verification

### Getting Industry Right

**Client says "SaaS companies"**

Break it down:
- B2B SaaS or B2C SaaS?
- What vertical? (MarTech, FinTech, HRTech, etc.)
- Stage? (Funded startups, established, public?)

**Client says "Healthcare"**

Clarify:
- Hospitals and health systems?
- Private practices?
- Healthcare technology?
- Pharma? Biotech? Medical devices?
- Insurance? Payers?

### Industry Verification Methods

1. **Website check** - Look at what they actually do
2. **LinkedIn** - Company industry classification
3. **G2/Capterra** - For software companies
4. **Crunchbase** - For startups/tech
5. **NAICS codes** - For precise classification

### Industry Red Flags

❌ Holding companies (no direct operations)
❌ Consulting firms (unless explicitly targeted)
❌ Non-profits (unless specified)
❌ Government (different sales motion)
❌ Educational institutions (unless specified)

---

## Geographic Targeting

### Common Geographic Scopes

| Scope | Considerations |
|-------|---------------|
| Single city | Time zone, local presence |
| State/Region | May have business reasons |
| Country | Language, business culture |
| Multi-country | GDPR, CAN-SPAM, compliance |
| Global | Time zones, localization |

### US Targeting Specifics

**By timezone:**
- Eastern: Most business activity, most competition
- Central: Often overlooked, good opportunity
- Mountain: Smaller market, specific industries
- Pacific: Tech-heavy, competitive

**By region:**
- Northeast: Finance, healthcare, professional services
- Southeast: Growing tech hubs, lower cost
- Midwest: Manufacturing, agriculture, insurance
- Southwest: Energy, aerospace, tech growth
- West Coast: Tech, entertainment, startups

### International Considerations

**Europe (GDPR):**
- Need lawful basis for outreach
- Typically use "legitimate interest"
- Must provide easy opt-out
- Keep records of consent/basis

**UK (post-Brexit):**
- UK GDPR applies
- Similar rules to EU

**Canada (CASL):**
- Stricter than US CAN-SPAM
- Need implied or express consent
- Business exemption exists for B2B

---

## Red Flags: Who to Exclude

### Always Exclude

**Competitors:**
- Direct competitors of client
- Indirect competitors
- Companies that offer similar solutions

**Agencies & Consultants:**
- Marketing agencies (unless targeted)
- Consulting firms
- Freelancers using company email

**Existing Relationships:**
- Current customers
- Active pipeline
- Past customers (unless win-back campaign)
- Active trials/demos

### Build an Exclusion List

Get from client:
- Competitor domains
- Current customer domains
- Partner domains (if needed)
- Any specific exclusions

### Industry-Specific Exclusions

**If client sells to enterprises:**
- Exclude startups (<50 employees)
- Exclude bootstrapped companies
- Exclude sole proprietorships

**If client sells to startups:**
- Exclude enterprises (>500 employees)
- Exclude government
- Exclude traditional/old-school industries

---

## ICP Verification Workflow

### Before Sourcing

1. **Document ICP in writing**
   - Titles (with variations)
   - Company size (range)
   - Industries (specific)
   - Geography
   - Exclusions

2. **Client approval**
   - Share ICP document
   - Get written confirmation
   - Clarify any ambiguities

### During Sourcing

3. **Build filters matching ICP**
4. **Pull sample of 50-100 leads**
5. **Manual review of sample:**
   - Check 10-20 companies against ICP
   - Verify titles on LinkedIn
   - Check company websites

6. **Adjust filters if needed**
7. **Pull full list**

### After Sourcing

8. **Random audit of 5-10%**
   - Should be >95% ICP match
   - Document any issues
   - Remove non-matches

9. **Edge cases**
   - When in doubt, ask client
   - Keep notes for future lists

---

## ICP Matching Scorecard

| Criteria | Weight | Score (1-5) |
|----------|--------|-------------|
| Title match | 30% | |
| Company size | 25% | |
| Industry match | 20% | |
| Geography | 15% | |
| No exclusions | 10% | |

**Scoring Guide:**
- 5: Perfect match
- 4: Strong match, minor variance
- 3: Acceptable, some flexibility
- 2: Marginal, needs review
- 1: Does not match, exclude

**Threshold:** Only include leads scoring 4.0+ weighted average.

guides.title: Mailbox Warmup Guidelines
guides.content:
# Mailbox Warmup Guidelines

A properly warmed mailbox is the foundation of deliverability. Skip or rush warmup, and your emails go straight to spam. This guide ensures every mailbox is campaign-ready.

---

## What Is Warmup?

Warmup is the process of building a positive sending reputation for a new email address by:

1. **Gradually increasing** send volume
2. **Generating engagement** (opens, replies, moving from spam)
3. **Establishing patterns** that ISPs recognize as legitimate

### Why It Matters

New email addresses have:
- No sending history
- No reputation (neutral is bad)
- ISPs treating them with suspicion

Warmup builds the trust needed to land in inbox.

---

## Minimum Warmup Period

### The 14-Day Minimum

**Absolute minimum:** 14 days of warmup before any outbound

**Recommended:** 21-28 days for best results

**For high-volume campaigns:** 30+ days

### Warmup Timeline

| Days | Status | Recommended Action |
|------|--------|-----------------|
| 1-7 | Building | Warmup only, zero outbound |
| 8-14 | Developing | Warmup only, monitor scores |
| 15-21 | Strengthening | Can start low-volume outbound |
| 22-28 | Mature | Normal campaign volume |
| 28+ | Established | Full capacity |

### Why 14 Days Minimum?

- ISPs track 14-30 day patterns
- Reputation builds gradually
- Rushing = spam folder
- Google specifically watches new senders for ~2 weeks

---

## Warmup Score Requirements

### Target Scores

| Score | Status | Action |
|-------|--------|---------|
| 90+ | ✅ Excellent | Ready for campaigns |
| 80-89 | ⚠️ Good | Can start with low volume |
| 70-79 | ⚠️ Fair | Continue warmup, don't campaign |
| Below 70 | ❌ Poor | Investigate issues, extend warmup |

### What Affects Warmup Score

**Positive factors:**
- Emails opened
- Replies received
- Moved from spam to inbox
- Marked as "not spam"

**Negative factors:**
- Bounces
- Spam complaints
- Ignored emails
- Emails left in spam

### Monitoring Warmup

Check scores daily during warmup:
1. Log into warmup tool (Instantly, Warmbox, Mailreach)
2. Check inbox placement rate
3. Check warmup score trend
4. Note any sudden drops

---

## Daily Sending Limits During Warmup

### Warmup-Only Period (Days 1-14)

**Warmup tool sends:** Let the tool manage (typically 30-50/day)

**Manual sends:** Minimal, only necessary business emails

**Outbound campaigns:** ZERO

### Transition Period (Days 15-21)

| Day | Warmup Emails | Campaign Emails | Total |
|-----|--------------|-----------------|-------|
| 15 | 40 | 10 | 50 |
| 16 | 40 | 15 | 55 |
| 17 | 35 | 20 | 55 |
| 18 | 35 | 25 | 60 |
| 19 | 30 | 30 | 60 |
| 20 | 30 | 35 | 65 |
| 21 | 25 | 40 | 65 |

### Established Period (Day 22+)

| Daily Limit | Total Sends | Warmup | Campaign |
|-------------|-------------|--------|----------|
| Conservative | 50-75 | 20-25 | 30-50 |
| Standard | 75-100 | 25-30 | 50-70 |
| Aggressive | 100-150 | 30-40 | 70-110 |

**Important:** Never exceed 150 emails/day per mailbox for cold outbound.

---

## When to Start Campaigns

### The Ready Checklist

- [ ] Minimum 14 days of warmup completed
- [ ] Warmup score consistently above 90
- [ ] No sudden score drops in last 5 days
- [ ] Inbox placement rate above 95%
- [ ] DKIM, SPF, DMARC properly configured
- [ ] Custom tracking domain set up
- [ ] Test emails landing in inbox (check with fresh Gmail)

### Starting Slow

**Week 1 of campaigns:**
- Max 30 emails/day/mailbox
- Monitor bounce rate closely
- Check inbox placement daily

**Week 2 of campaigns:**
- Can increase to 50 emails/day
- Continue monitoring
- Adjust based on performance

**Week 3+:**
- Full capacity (based on limits above)
- Maintain monitoring routine

### When NOT to Start

❌ Warmup score below 80
❌ Sudden score drop in last week
❌ High bounce rate during warmup
❌ SPF/DKIM not configured
❌ Less than 14 days of warmup
❌ Previous deliverability issues unresolved

---

## Signs of Deliverability Issues

### Early Warning Signs

| Signal | What It Means | Action |
|--------|--------------|--------|
| Score drops >10 points suddenly | ISP flagging | Pause, investigate |
| Bounce rate >5% | List or tech issue | Clean list, check DNS |
| Inbox placement <90% | Reputation damage | Reduce volume, check content |
| Open rate sudden drop | Landing in spam | Pause campaign, check |
| Spam complaints | Content or list issue | Immediate pause, review |

### How to Monitor

**Daily checks:**
1. Warmup tool score
2. Campaign bounce rate
3. Open rate trends
4. Reply rate trends

**Weekly checks:**
1. Send test emails to Gmail, Outlook
2. Check MXToolbox for blacklists
3. Review any spam complaints
4. Analyze which content performs best

### Red Alert Situations

**PAUSE IMMEDIATELY if:**
- Bounce rate exceeds 5%
- Multiple spam complaints
- Sudden open rate drop (>50%)
- Warmup score drops below 70
- Any blacklist detection

### Recovery Steps

1. **Stop all outbound campaigns**
2. **Continue warmup only**
3. **Investigate cause:**
   - List quality issue?
   - DNS/tech problem?
   - Content triggering spam?
   - Sending too fast?
4. **Fix root cause**
5. **Monitor for 7-14 days**
6. **Restart campaigns slowly**

---

## Warmup Best Practices

### Technical Setup First

Before warmup even starts:
- [ ] SPF record configured
- [ ] DKIM signing enabled
- [ ] DMARC policy set (start with p=none)
- [ ] Custom tracking domain
- [ ] Mailbox connected to warmup tool

### During Warmup

**Do:**
✅ Let warmup run 24/7
✅ Keep warmup running even after campaigns start
✅ Respond to any legitimate emails
✅ Monitor scores daily
✅ Be patient

**Don't:**
❌ Rush the process
❌ Send campaigns before ready
❌ Disable warmup once campaigns start
❌ Ignore warning signs
❌ Use one mailbox for too many sends

### Maintaining Warmup

**After campaigns start:**
- Keep warmup at 20-30 emails/day
- Never fully disable warmup
- Warmup maintains reputation during low-send periods
- Weekends: warmup only (no campaigns)

---

## Warmup Tools Comparison

| Tool | Emails/Month | Features | Best For |
|------|-------------|----------|----------|
| Instantly (built-in) | Included | Auto-adjustment, analytics | Instantly users |
| Mailreach | 15K+ | Detailed reporting | Serious senders |
| Warmbox | 15K+ | Multi-provider | Diverse setups |
| Lemwarm | 10K+ | Lemlist integrated | Lemlist users |

### Tool Setup Checklist

1. Connect mailbox via IMAP/SMTP or OAuth
2. Configure warmup schedule (start low)
3. Enable automatic replies
4. Set positive engagement actions
5. Monitor dashboard daily

---

## Quick Reference

| Element | Guideline |
|---------|-----------|
| Minimum warmup | 14 days |
| Ideal warmup | 21-28 days |
| Target score | >90 |
| Min score to campaign | 80 |
| Daily send limit | 50-100 max |
| Keep warmup running | Always |
| Check scores | Daily |

guides.title: Campaign Strategy Checklist
guides.content:
# Campaign Strategy Checklist

Great campaigns don't happen by accident. This checklist ensures every campaign is set up for success from day one.

---

## Phase 1: Understanding Client's Offer

### What You Need to Know

Before writing a single email, understand:

**The Product/Service:**
- [ ] What exactly does the client sell?
- [ ] What problem does it solve?
- [ ] What's the core value proposition?
- [ ] What makes it different from competitors?
- [ ] What are the key features/benefits?

**The Business Model:**
- [ ] What's the pricing model? (SaaS, retainer, project-based)
- [ ] What's the average deal size?
- [ ] What's the typical sales cycle length?
- [ ] Is there a free trial or demo process?

**Social Proof:**
- [ ] What case studies exist?
- [ ] Any specific results/metrics to highlight?
- [ ] Notable clients/logos to mention?
- [ ] Reviews or testimonials?

### Questions to Ask Client

1. "Walk me through what happens after someone books a call with you."
2. "Who is your best customer and why?"
3. "What made your last 5 clients choose you over alternatives?"
4. "What objections do you commonly hear?"
5. "What's the biggest result you've achieved for a client?"

---

## Phase 2: Defining Clear ICP

### ICP Documentation

Get SPECIFIC answers:

**Target Titles:**
- [ ] Primary decision maker title(s)
- [ ] Secondary influencer titles
- [ ] Title variations to include
- [ ] Titles to explicitly exclude

**Company Profile:**
- [ ] Industry/vertical (be specific)
- [ ] Company size range (employees)
- [ ] Revenue range (if applicable)
- [ ] Funding stage (if relevant)
- [ ] Tech stack requirements (if any)

**Geography:**
- [ ] Target countries
- [ ] Target regions/states
- [ ] Timezone considerations
- [ ] Any exclusions

**Exclusions:**
- [ ] Competitor domains
- [ ] Current customer domains
- [ ] Partner domains
- [ ] Any other exclusions

### ICP Validation

- [ ] Does client have customers matching this ICP?
- [ ] Are there enough leads in this ICP for campaign?
- [ ] Is this ICP reachable via cold email?
- [ ] Does client's offer make sense for this ICP?

---

## Phase 3: Value Proposition Clarity

### The Value Prop Framework

**Answer these three questions:**

1. **WHO** do you help?
   - Specific titles + company types
   - "We help B2B SaaS companies with 50-500 employees"

2. **WHAT** do you help them achieve?
   - Specific outcome, not feature
   - "Book 15-20 qualified demos per month"

3. **HOW** do you do it differently?
   - Unique approach or advantage
   - "Using data-driven targeting and multi-channel outreach"

### Value Prop Templates

**Template 1: Result-focused**
```
We help [WHO] [ACHIEVE WHAT] through [METHOD].
```

**Template 2: Problem-focused**
```
We help [WHO] solve [PROBLEM] so they can [BENEFIT].
```

**Template 3: Comparison**
```
We help [WHO] go from [CURRENT STATE] to [DESIRED STATE].
```

### Value Prop Checklist

- [ ] Written in one clear sentence
- [ ] Specific and measurable
- [ ] Believable (not hype)
- [ ] Different from competitors
- [ ] Approved by client

---

## Phase 4: Campaign Naming Conventions

### Standard Naming Format

```
[CLIENT]-[ICP]-[ANGLE]-[DATE]-[VARIANT]
```

**Examples:**
- `ACME-VP-Sales-Pain-Feb25-A`
- `ACME-CTO-Case-Study-Feb25-B`
- `ACME-Directors-Scale-Mar25-A`

### Components

| Component | Description | Examples |
|-----------|-------------|----------|
| CLIENT | Short client name | ACME, XYZ |
| ICP | Target persona | VP-Sales, CTO, Directors |
| ANGLE | Email approach | Pain, Case-Study, Direct |
| DATE | Launch month/year | Feb25, Mar25 |
| VARIANT | A/B test version | A, B, C |

### Why Naming Matters

- Easy to identify in dashboards
- Quick filtering and analysis
- Clear A/B test tracking
- Historical reference
- Team alignment

### Campaign Organization

**Folder structure in Instantly/Bison:**
```
Client Name/
  ├── Active/
  │   ├── [campaign-name-A]
  │   └── [campaign-name-B]
  ├── Paused/
  ├── Completed/
  └── Tests/
```

---

## Phase 5: Tracking Setup

### Required Tracking

**Email Platform Tracking:**
- [ ] Open tracking enabled
- [ ] Click tracking enabled (via custom domain)
- [ ] Reply tracking enabled
- [ ] Bounce tracking enabled

**Custom Tracking Domain:**
- [ ] Subdomain created (e.g., track.clientdomain.com)
- [ ] DNS records configured
- [ ] SSL certificate active
- [ ] Tested and working

**CRM Integration (if applicable):**
- [ ] Leads syncing to CRM
- [ ] Reply tagging working
- [ ] Meeting bookings tracked
- [ ] Pipeline stages connected

### Tracking Dashboard Setup

**Metrics to Monitor:**

| Metric | Target | Alert If |
|--------|--------|----------|
| Open Rate | >50% | <30% |
| Reply Rate | >3% | <1% |
| Bounce Rate | <2% | >5% |
| Positive Reply % | >30% of replies | <20% |

### UTM Parameters (if using links)

```
?utm_source=cold_email
&utm_medium=email
&utm_campaign=[campaign-name]
&utm_content=[email-number]
```

---

## Phase 6: Pre-Launch Checklist

### Technical Verification

- [ ] Mailboxes warmed (14+ days, score >90)
- [ ] SPF/DKIM/DMARC configured
- [ ] Custom tracking domain working
- [ ] Test emails landing in inbox
- [ ] All merge fields tested
- [ ] Spintax variations verified
- [ ] Links working and tracked

### Content Verification

- [ ] All copy reviewed for spam triggers
- [ ] Personalization fields populated
- [ ] CTA is clear and single
- [ ] Sequence timing configured
- [ ] Follow-ups properly connected
- [ ] Breakup email included

### List Verification

- [ ] Leads match ICP criteria
- [ ] Email validation completed
- [ ] Deduplicated against active campaigns
- [ ] No role-based emails
- [ ] No competitor/exclusion domains
- [ ] Minimum list size met

### Client Approval

- [ ] Copy approved by client
- [ ] ICP confirmed
- [ ] Start date confirmed
- [ ] Reporting cadence agreed

---

## Campaign Launch Checklist

### Day of Launch

1. [ ] Final test email sent and checked
2. [ ] Campaign status set to "Active"
3. [ ] Sending schedule confirmed
4. [ ] First emails going out
5. [ ] Monitor for first hour
6. [ ] Check bounce rate after 50 sends

### Day 1 Check

- [ ] Emails sending as expected
- [ ] Bounce rate under 5%
- [ ] No immediate spam complaints
- [ ] Opens registering

### Day 3 Check

- [ ] Open rate tracking
- [ ] First replies coming in
- [ ] No deliverability issues
- [ ] Follow-ups triggered correctly

### Week 1 Review

- [ ] Full metrics review
- [ ] Reply categorization
- [ ] Any needed adjustments
- [ ] Client update

---

## Quick Reference

| Phase | Key Deliverable |
|-------|----------------|
| 1. Offer | Written understanding of product/service |
| 2. ICP | Documented, specific targeting criteria |
| 3. Value Prop | One-sentence, approved statement |
| 4. Naming | Consistent, trackable campaign names |
| 5. Tracking | All tracking verified and working |
| 6. Launch | All checklists completed |

guides.title: Loom Video Requirements
guides.content:
# Loom Video Requirements

Client Loom videos are essential for onboarding and strategy alignment. This guide ensures every Loom delivers the information needed for successful campaigns.

---

## Purpose of Client Loom

The client Loom is their chance to give you:
- Context that can't be captured in forms
- Their voice and tone for copy
- Real understanding of their offer
- Insights into their best customers
- What matters most to them

### When to Request

**During onboarding:**
- After initial discovery call
- Before writing any copy
- As part of intake process

**During campaign:**
- When pivoting strategy
- When targeting new ICP
- After significant feedback

---

## Length Guidelines

### Target: 5-10 Minutes

| Length | Assessment |
|--------|------------|
| Under 3 min | Too short, missing info |
| 3-5 min | Acceptable for simple offers |
| 5-10 min | **Ideal range** |
| 10-15 min | Acceptable if detailed |
| Over 15 min | Too long, needs focus |

### Why This Length?

**Too short:**
- Missing critical context
- Surface-level information
- Need more follow-up questions

**Too long:**
- Hard to extract key points
- May include irrelevant info
- Time-consuming to review

### Tip for Clients

"Keep it conversational — 7-8 minutes is perfect. Cover the key sections and don't worry about being polished. We just need to understand your business."

---

## Required Sections

### Section 1: The Offer (2-3 min)

**What they should cover:**

- [ ] What do you sell? (product/service)
- [ ] What problem does it solve?
- [ ] Who is it for? (in their words)
- [ ] What makes you different?
- [ ] What are the main benefits?

**What to listen for:**
- Unique angles for copy
- Language they use naturally
- Specific outcomes they mention
- Confidence/passion areas

### Section 2: Ideal Customer (2-3 min)

**What they should cover:**

- [ ] Who is your BEST customer?
- [ ] What titles do they hold?
- [ ] What size companies?
- [ ] What industries?
- [ ] What triggers them to buy?

**What to listen for:**
- Specific customer stories
- Common patterns
- Non-obvious ICP insights
- Exclusions ("not companies that...")

### Section 3: Success Stories (1-2 min)

**What they should cover:**

- [ ] Best case study or success story
- [ ] Specific results achieved
- [ ] Timeline of results
- [ ] Any metrics to share?

**What to listen for:**
- Quotable results
- Specific numbers
- Client names (if shareable)
- Before/after scenarios

### Section 4: Sales Process (1-2 min)

**What they should cover:**

- [ ] What happens after someone books a call?
- [ ] What's the typical sales cycle?
- [ ] What objections come up?
- [ ] What helps close deals?

**What to listen for:**
- What makes a qualified lead
- Red flags they see
- What to mention/avoid in emails
- Their sales approach

### Section 5: Additional Context (1 min)

**What they should cover:**

- [ ] Anything else we should know?
- [ ] Past cold email experience?
- [ ] What's worked/not worked?
- [ ] Any specific requests?

**What to listen for:**
- Past learnings
- Specific preferences
- Concerns or priorities
- Personality and tone

---

## Loom Request Template

### Email to Client

```
Subject: Quick Loom request — 5-10 minutes

Hey [Name],

Excited to kick things off! Before I start writing your campaigns, 
I need a quick Loom from you (5-10 min).

Please cover:

1. **Your Offer** (2-3 min)
   - What do you sell and what problem does it solve?
   - What makes you different from alternatives?

2. **Your Ideal Customer** (2-3 min)
   - Describe your best customer
   - What titles, company sizes, industries?
   - What makes someone a great fit vs. not a fit?

3. **Success Story** (1-2 min)
   - Walk me through your best case study
   - Any specific results or metrics?

4. **Sales Process** (1 min)
   - What happens after someone books a call?
   - What objections do you commonly hear?

5. **Anything Else** (1 min)
   - Past cold email experience?
   - Specific things you want me to know?

Just talk naturally — no script needed. This helps me write copy 
that sounds like you and resonates with your audience.

Loom link when ready: [reply to this email]

Thanks!
[Your Name]
```

---

## What Makes a Good Loom

### Good Loom Characteristics

✅ Covers all required sections
✅ Provides specific examples
✅ Shows their personality/tone
✅ Mentions real customer stories
✅ Includes specific metrics
✅ Stays focused and on-topic
✅ 5-10 minutes long

### Red Flags in Looms

⚠️ Too vague ("we help businesses grow")
⚠️ No specific customer examples
⚠️ Unclear on ICP
⚠️ No results or case studies
⚠️ Under 3 minutes
⚠️ Over 20 minutes with tangents

### Follow-up Questions

If Loom is missing info, ask:

1. "Can you give me a specific example of [X]?"
2. "What titles specifically should we target?"
3. "What's a specific result you achieved for a client?"
4. "Who should we NOT reach out to?"
5. "What makes someone a bad fit?"

---

## Processing the Loom

### Step 1: Watch and Timestamp

Create notes with timestamps:

```
0:00 - Intro
0:45 - Main offer description
2:30 - Key differentiator mentioned
4:15 - ICP details
6:00 - Case study: [Client] - [Result]
7:30 - Sales process
8:45 - Past experience notes
```

### Step 2: Extract Key Elements

**Value Prop:**
- [One-sentence summary of their offer]

**ICP:**
- Titles: [List]
- Industries: [List]
- Company size: [Range]
- Exclusions: [List]

**Proof Points:**
- Case study: [Client, result]
- Metrics: [Specific numbers]

**Tone/Voice Notes:**
- [How they speak, energy level, formality]

### Step 3: Identify Copy Angles

Pull potential email angles:
- Pain point angle
- Case study angle
- Direct offer angle
- Curiosity angle

### Step 4: Document Questions

List any gaps that need clarification before writing.

---

## Approval Process

### Before Campaign Launch

1. **Write copy based on Loom**
2. **Share drafts with client**
3. **Request feedback:**
   - Does this sound like you?
   - Any facts wrong?
   - Any changes needed?
4. **Incorporate feedback**
5. **Get written approval**

### Approval Request Template

```
Subject: Campaign copy ready for review

Hey [Name],

Here's the campaign copy based on your Loom. Please review:

[Link to copy doc]

Specifically let me know:
1. Does the tone sound right?
2. Are all facts/claims accurate?
3. Any changes you'd like?

Once you approve, we'll schedule the campaign for [Date].

Thanks!
[Your Name]
```

### Approval Confirmation

Always get written approval:
- Email confirmation works
- Slack/Teams message works
- Document with checkboxes works

**Keep approval on file** for reference.

---

## Loom Checklist

### Requesting

- [ ] Sent clear Loom request with sections
- [ ] Specified 5-10 minute target
- [ ] Provided example of what you need

### Reviewing

- [ ] All 5 sections covered
- [ ] Specific examples provided
- [ ] Clear ICP definition
- [ ] At least one case study/result
- [ ] Sales process understood

### Processing

- [ ] Timestamped notes created
- [ ] Key elements extracted
- [ ] Copy angles identified
- [ ] Follow-up questions listed
- [ ] Clarifications requested (if needed)

### Approval

- [ ] Copy shared with client
- [ ] Feedback received and incorporated
- [ ] Written approval obtained
- [ ] Approval documented/filed

---

## Quick Reference

| Element | Guideline |
|---------|-----------|
| Length | 5-10 minutes |
| Sections | 5 required |
| Delivery | Loom video link |
| Processing | Timestamp + extract |
| Approval | Written confirmation required |
